questions.question_text: What is the man going to do?

options.text: He is going to leave his present job.
He is going to attend a job interview.
He will meet his new manager in two weeks.
He will tell the management how he really feels.

questions.question_text: What does the woman say about the man's feedback on the company?

options.text: It should be carefully analyzed.
It should be kept private.
It can be quite useful to senior managers.
It can improve interviewees' job prospects.

questions.question_text: What is the man worried about?

options.text: It may do harm to his fellow employees.
It may displease his immediate superiors.
It may adversely affect his future career prospects.
It may leave a negative impression on the interviewer.

questions.question_text: What does the woman suggest the man do?

options.text: Pour out his frustrations on a rate-your-employer website.
Network with his close friends to find a better employer.
Do some practice for the exit interview.
Prepare a comprehensive exit report.

questions.question_text: What is the woman mainly talking about?

options.text: Her career as a botanist.
Her latest documentary.
Her month-long expedition.
Her unsuccessful journey.

questions.question_text: What does the woman say about her trip?

options.text: She was caught in a hurricane.
She had to live like a vegetarian.
She suffered from water shortage.
She had to endure many hardships.

questions.question_text: Why did the woman and her team have to leave the forest earlier than planned?

options.text: They could no longer bear the humidity.
They had no more food in the canoe.
A flood was approaching.
A hurricane was coming.

questions.question_text: What does the woman think of her trip?

options.text: It was memorable.
It was fruitful.
It was unbeatable.
It was uneventful.

questions.question_text: What is the effect of scientists using jargon in their communication?

options.text: It ensures the accuracy of their arguments.
It diminishes laymen's interest in science.
It hurts laymen's dignity and self-esteem.
It makes their expressions more explicit.

questions.question_text: How do laymen usually feel when scientists use jargon?

options.text: They will see the complexity of science.
They feel great respect towards scientists.
They tend to disbelieve the actual science.
They can learn to communicate with scientists.

questions.question_text: What should scientists do when communicating with laymen?

options.text: Explain all the jargon terms.
Do away with jargon terms.
Find appropriate topics.
Stimulate their interest.

questions.question_text: What was the initial concern about the local gassy hill?

options.text: There were oil deposits below a local gassy hill.
The erupting gas might endanger local children.
There was oil-leakage along the Gulf Coast.
The local gassy hill might start a huge fire.

questions.question_text: What was the major obstacle to drilling through the sand under the hill?

options.text: The massive gas underground.
Their lack of the needed skill.
Their lack of suitable tools.
The sand under the hill.

questions.question_text: What does the passage say about the new drilling method?

options.text: It was not as effective as he claimed.
It rendered many oil workers jobless.
It gave birth to the oil drilling industry.
It was not popularized until years later.

questions.question_text: What was the impact of the discovery of oil in Texas?

options.text: It ruined the state's cotton and beef industries.
It resulted in an oil surplus all over the world.
It resumed in an oil surplus all over the world.
It radically transformed the state's economy.

questions.question_text: What is mentioned as a major reason for employees to quit?

options.text: Insufficient motivation.
Tough regulations.
Unsuitable jobs.
Bad managers.

questions.question_text: What is another reason for employees to quit according to the talk?

options.text: Ineffective training.
Toxic company culture.
Overburdening of managers.
Lack of regular evaluation.
